posts.name: Sumter Link
posts.cooked:
During the off-season we are going to work on speeding up our climber.  It is styled after 5987’s.  We want to try to utilize the AndyMark ratchet sport ( AM -5409) to handle the back drive and allow us to use a lower gear ratio, but we will need to modify it because we are not using a 57 sport gear box to drive the climber.

The idea is to take the ratchet sport gear ( AM -4398) and put a half inch hex bore in the center of it.  Our machining capabilities are limited but we do have a large arbor press and the AndyMark 1/2" Hex Broach ( AM - 2204).  I am very familiar with how to do this with aluminum.  However, the ratchet sport gear is steel and I have never tried to broach steel.  Is that even possible?

posts.name: AgentSmith451
posts.cooked: It should be doable, very slowly and with lots of cutting oil. However you might have better luck just getting a new part waterjet or laser cut from someplace like sendcutsend.

posts.name: Sumter Link
posts.cooked: Excellent, and we might give that a try.  We have never used any vendor like that and one of the aspects of the project I like is its the perfect type of part to get figure out how those places work.  Does your team use sendcutsend often?

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
What exactly are you trying to replace or modify?

Waterjet and Laser are not precise enough for typical gear profiles.

The broach will handle steel just fine, as long as it’s not too deep of a part. We typically broached 1/2" thick steel gears back in the day with the same broach tool, using a 40T manually actuated hydraulic press (it was overkill).

Watch the alignment on its way through and frequently release pressure to realign. We shattered an embarrassing number of broaches over my two years on 192.

posts.name: Sumter Link
posts.cooked:
The idea is to broach this:

This gear is used in the Ratchet Sport, facilitating single directional movement. The four holes interface with a 4:1 carrier plate to transfer torque and the profile in the center engages with a 16 tooth pinion gear from the input motor.

posts.name: AgentSmith451
posts.cooked:
We used Fabworks this season for the top and bottom pieces of the CAGE assembly, I believe there is a $30 SendCutSend voucher available to all teams.

Something you could also do to ensure a good fit on the hex shaft would be specifying a hex just under 1/2", so the broach could square up the sides if there’s a draft from the cut. For the outside ratchet shape that could be tumbled or hand-finished if needed for surface smoothness.

posts.name: Joe Johnson
posts.cooked:
s-neff:

Waterjet and Laser are not precise enough for typical gear profiles.

CITATION NEEDED. I waterjet gears all the time.

Sure, if you try waterjetting a .5module (or say 48 DP) gear that’s a half inch thick, you are going to have a bad day but larger teeth and/or thinner face width gears are very easily cut via waterjet.

Whenever I have a waterjet available to me (how I miss the Global Max at my prior employer), somehow the teams I mentor manage to find a need for a waterjet gear (or ten) on their robot.

Dr. Joe J.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Other than the obvious backordered issue is there a reason not  to get a part that is already hex or easier to broach?

The Friction Brake allows you to aid your PID controller in holding an arm, elevator or another subsystem in place or even completely hold your mechanism in place without any motor power! Easy integration with your design Same 1.875" bolt pattern as...

Price: USD 34.99

The existing bore on the AM one will be difficult to deal with unless you carefully mount it to a fixture and open the bore up on a mill/lathe. Drilling that special bore out with a twist drill has a really low chance of succeeding imo

Send cut send / fabworks for some steel ratchet plates you stack together and clean up is another option. Sure they are not hardened, but that shouldn’t matter for the life cycle of the part in this particular application ( FRC ).

Others have had luck with high quality 3d printing ratchets as long as the loads are reasonable and or other modifications to COTS using printed housings.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Broaching steel is perfectly doable. It will likely require more force than broaching aluminum, so you may need to be a little more careful in setup, but you’ll probably be fine.

1/2" HSS Hexagon Broach

This broach is excellent to use for aluminum, mild steel, and it cuts plastic like butter.

You may want to check that the Ratchet Sport Gear is mild steel, it just lists the material as ‘steel.’

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: 1/2" Hex Broaching steel is doable, but it will depend on the size of your press (and how rigidly it’s mounted) and take a combination of elbow grease and patience. Don’t force it through, be careful of your alignment, don’t break the broach, and use cutting fluid.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
For this particular part (which is 4140) I am going to point this out again… You will need to open up the bore and that is not a simple drilling operation in this case due to the complexity of that bore. posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
Joe_Johnson:

I waterjet gears all the time.

Sure, if you try waterjetting a .5module (or say 48 DP) gear that’s a half inch thick, you are going to have a bad day but larger teeth and/or thinner face width gears are very easily cut via waterjet.

I know I’ve learned a lot about gears and gearboxes from your posts over the past 20-ish years—and that makes me hopeful that you might share the process parameters that you’ve found successful.

Do you need a kerf-compensating waterjet head , particular feed rates, post-cut finishing operations or metrology capabilities to end up with a good finished product?

How does it compare, in terms of quality, cost and time, to what was the gold standard for completely custom gears for FRC in the past, wire EDM? Or admittedly compromised options like smallish laser cutters and lower-end CNC routers and mills?

What surface finish and amount of profile variation are you aiming for, and how much of that is a concession to the short working life and low stakes of FRC competition, versus a piece of machinery?

posts.name: Sumter Link
posts.cooked:
I appreciate the advice on this and I too have been skeptical to the drilling aspect of this as much as I am the broaching.  I think that even if we give this a try we will also experiment with send cut send or fabworks.  I also might try to have a nearby team that has access to a lathe and better machining equipment help us out.  One of the reasons that I like this as an off season is that the part is inexpensive and it will get us familiar with some of these other machining resources that could be available.  During the build season trying to figure out something like fabworks for the first time can be overwhelming.

Also, thanks for sharing the part from West Coast Products.  The reason that I haven’t been looking at it is simply that I have had issues getting them approved as a vendor at my school and purchasing from AndyMark is simply easier.

posts.name: Gene Jamison
posts.cooked: Seems like the print is wrong, as it shows the four thru holes on a 0.441 bolt hole circle which would not leave anything to broach a 1/2" hex is true.

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Can you live with a “triangle” profile instead of “Hex”. With triangle, you could machine it with, say 3/16" end mill.

Either way to alignment is going to be a little tricky but doable.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
5 edits later… Accepting a sloppy 0.002" FRC -hex fit as normal and sufficient, the biggest issue is probably interfacing to the 4:1 stage pin outputs, and that’s best done by modifying the Andymark part rather than using a custom blank.

Clamp it good, drill it carefully with floorstanding drillpress or mill and sharp cobalt bit, bail and go to a bigger machine if needed. Low speed, slow feed. Don’t expect a benchtop drill press to work. Broaching the 4140 should be fine, especially at just 3/8" thickness - that’s not uncommon for gears. Might need 40T+ rated hydraulic press.

MSU2000:

Can you live with a “triangle” profile instead of “Hex”. With triangle, you could machine it with, say 3/16" end mill.

If you have a CNC that’ll do steel, this is probably a much faster and higher precision option than any of my suggestions. (Or a manual mill and a rotary table attachment and patience). Or ordering the triangle through online laser/waterjet of choice, but then you’re stuck drilling the interface pin holes to size by hand and might lose necessary precision at that stage.

If you make it from 4140, you can harden it yourself too

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: I think the print has a typo, its probbaly .882" bolt Dia Circle.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: 4140 is definitely hardenable, so I would not assume this particular part is machinable. As to the more general question that comes up in FRC surprisingly regularly: Can you mill/drill/lathe/broach/nibble/grind/saw steel? Yes, mild steel is the most common metal for basically every fabrication process, and basically every metal fabrication tool is designed for mild steel first. Steels very widely. The most common material for blades and bits to cut steel was steel, and its still very common though carbide seems to be everywhere these days. You need to be asking “What kind of steel is this?”, not “Can I cut steel?”.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
All normal broaches are actually designed to work on steel!

You MUST use cutting oil when you do it, and the forces will be quite a bit larger,but not nutty.

The key crash landing for broaches in our applications is length of part.  Too long and the tooth gullets fill up.  The Kraken spline broach is oarticularly bad about this!

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Or you could probably skip all of these and I would just order one (or a few) from Send Cut Send with slight material safe on the hex made out of mild steel or harder one like AR500, then diamond file them to fit snug to the shaft. Its Laser Cut part, so +/- .005" is probably at best and surface finish is sketchy and might need some work. Its probably cost $10 or less each.

But learning to broach is fun too.
